content: The "Home Health Access Preservation Act of 1998" revises the per beneficiary limit. The "Home Health Access Preservation Act of 1998" amends Section 1861(v)(1)(L) of the Social Security Act to provide an interim system of limits for home health agencies' services starting from October 1, 1998. Payment is capped at the agency-specific per beneficiary annual limitation. The "Home Health Access Preservation Act of 1998" amends Section 1861(v)(1)(L) of the Social Security Act to provide an interim system of limits for home health agencies' services starting from October 1, 1998. Payment is capped at the agency-specific per beneficiary annual limitation, which is determined based on the agency's unduplicated census count of patients entitled to benefits under this title for the cost reporting period. The "Home Health Access Preservation Act of 1998" sets interim payment limits for home health agencies based on their location within different census divisions, ranging from $3,523.50 to $4,672.50. The "Home Health Access Preservation Act of 1998" establishes interim payment limits for home health agencies based on their location within different census divisions, ranging from $3,523.50 to $4,946.50. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to reflect these changes. Amendments to the Social Security Act for beneficiaries will take effect on October 1, 1998. SEC. 3. INCREASED PAYMENTS FOR HOME HEALTH AGENCIES SERVING CERTAIN BENEFICIARIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates savings to the Medicare Program each fiscal year. If savings are projected, increased payments will be prescribed. The Secretary of Health and Human Services prescribes rules for increased payments to home health agencies under the Medicare Program based on patient days. The total increased payments in a fiscal year equal the estimated savings. The Secretary determines the increased payment amount annually, starting in 1998. The Secretary will establish increased payment amounts within 30 days of the Act's enactment and implement heightened scrutiny for certain Medicare reimbursement claims. SEC. 4 of the Act increases per-visit cost limits from 105 percent to 108 percent, effective October 1, 1998. SEC. 5 requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to provide updates on the implementation of the prospective payment system for home health agencies every 90 days.
